ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned some basic skills about genetics and development.
Mostly genetics, more so than evo-devo
I definitely learned how to write a research proposal effectively.

I felt like I gained very little knowledge from lectures, which often seemed almost haphazardly organized and unnecessarily difficult to follow. One of the most frustrating elements of the class was the final, which seemed almost inhumanly difficult and in no way reflective of what we had supposedly learned over the course of the half-semester.
How to apply scientific skepticism to different applications, in addition to understanding the basics of genetics and developmental biology.

You'll learn how to create a research proposal. This course gives you tools to study the pathways of development and disease. You'll learn a lot about the methods of study, and the pros and cons of different approaches.
I really liked learning about sex determination (SRY gene in the Y chromosome), and thought it was interesting how the concentration of gene expression affects body development.
A learned a ton about developmental biology that I did not know and some of the approaches people use to study developmental and genetic biology.

I learned a lot of research techniques in writing the research paper. I also kind of learned the fundamentals of genetics, but not really because I couldn't unpack the research studies that were presented in class.

Research methods related to identifying genetic trends across individuals and across species, the intellectual groundwork to understand these research methods, the process and structure of research proposals.
I learned a lot about how development works and the methods scientists use in order to determine all of these things. Necessary vs sufficient!

This class taught me about many different things: cancer, stem cells, embryology, homologous genes and conservation of development plus more. It was a collection of many different subsections of biology. I found the material quite interesting even though the class itself was hard.
I gained a basic knowledge of genetics and development. I learned about gene expression and how to regulate it. I learned about how genetics relates to disease.

I gained the skills of synthesizing information acquired throughout the entirety of the course into a cohesive understanding of biological understandings related to genetics and development. I learned a great deal about biological development.
BIOL 103 taught me how to write a proper research proposal and how to study genes and their functions.
I learned foundational theories, primary literature, and laboratory techniques governing developmental biology and genetics.

I learned about embryogenesis and differentiation, cancer, and the basics of genetics. I also learned about experimental tools and studies that contributed to discoveries about genetics and development.
I learned about genetics and development and the biological techniques used to figure them out.

Not really introduction to genetics and development but more of like case by case experiments and situations that demonstrate genetic principles that could be confusing; more experience in test taking under pressure which is not the most favorable of experiences; more experience in navigating confusing teachers

I think I learned a lot about genetics and the different processes of development, how it is affected and can easily be altered in different levels of development, beginning with genes. I learned also how to teach myself in this course because the professor didn't do well at explaining the information and I was able to use multiple resources to help myself.
We learned (or were expected to learn) some fine minutiae from development with a lecture or two on genetics.
Knowledge of developmental biology, genetics, transcription factors, cancers, various illnesses.
I grasped the field of genetic science and engineering. The material was very interesting.
I learned the basic phases of organism development, genetic principles, and some details on cancer, stem cells, epigenetics and hormones.
Better study habits, or at least different ones.
General genetics knowledge
I learned a small amount about genetics and development across species. This class was taught so poorly that I was unable to develop a meaningful understanding of the material.
Learned about development in biology.
I developed the skills necessary to design my own hypothesis and write a scientific paper.
Learned how to write a research proposal, read and understand scientific articles, and apply my knowledge of genetics and development to novel situations/designing experiments
I developed the knowledge of various aspects of development that I didn't know before. I additionally gained the skills of biological research and crafting a research proposal.
Pretty limited.
understanding experiments and applying concepts to design own research proposal
I learned about various aspects of genetics and development.
I gained a very basic understanding of key development concepts.

In this course, I learned the basics of genetics, including Morgan's laws, Mendel's laws and determining probabilities with Punnett squares, as well as developmental processes in the embryo and beyond. I learned to develop experimental approaches from a developmental biologist's point of view, like by breeding organisms with specific alleles or using a forwards/reverse genetics approach.

This course provided a thorough understanding of organismal development, and how these processes are applied through the specific situational usage of genes and their products. I found the research proposal we did for homework very interesting and provided a meaningful learning opportunity for me to use the research skills that contemporary scientists use in biology.
A comprehensive understanding of genetics and development: genetic regulation, mutations, diseases, and the passing of genetic information. Also how to write a research paper.
I learned a lot about genetics and development and I learned how to do science research and write a research proposal. This was a very valuable skill I think will be very helpful in the future.
I learned how to memorize a bunch of facts and apply some in scientific questions.

I think BIOL 103 really built on the critical thinking skills awarded from prior courses in the sequence. Although the knowledge isn't something I am particularly interested in, BIOL 103 really did help me to understand what it means to think like a scientist and to see things critically.
You learn about genetics and embryonic developenny and all of the factors that can influence development both positIvely and negatively.
Learnt about various different analytical methods and techniques, as well as many areas of genetics and development
I learned general concepts about how genetic processes control development, as well as specific examples from model organisms and/or neurodevelopment.
Some knowledge of genetics and the functioning of genes and inheritance.
I developed some of the skills necessary to write a research proposal, and also gained a much better understanding of various research methods.
I suppose I learned more about genes and the research process.
Understanding of the basic concepts of developmental biology and genetics.
I learned about the basics of genetics and development through the teaching of experiments that changed our scientific understanding of how life is programmed and how it carries out said program.

I'm going to be honest I don't really feel like I developed new skills persay. Sure, I used persistence to grind through convoluted assignments and poorly worded lecture slides but I don't think any new skills were developed.

By taking this course, I learned a lot about development, something that seemed very sparcely discussed in high school. The demanding course material also taught me to stay on top of studying, and how to keep up with dense and fast paced material!
Learned about embryonic development and cell differentiation.

I learned a ton about the developmental process and about genetics at the DNA level. This class was definitely a good intro course on these subjects. I also generated my first research paper and learned the skills necessary for doing so.
I learned how to memorize facts under pressure, and how to write a research proposal.
I learned about how genetics experiments are designed and their outcomes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was very poorly taught. While the material itself was very interesting, the professor did not do a good job actually explaining the concepts. As a student in the class, you had to rely on peer tutors and your own understanding to actually learn any of the material.
The slides didnt explain the concepts very well, but the professor tried to challenge us to think critically.

Enrichment should be provided to everyone. It made me understand things I wouldn't have ever otherwise. The professor also doesn't answer questions - he cuts students off and everything is unclear then. Therefore, you have to use Piazza or ask your TA - many of whom don't understand or speak English. On Piazza, only Prof Park answers really.

This class had very few strengths other than the deeply interesting aspects of the material, even though these were not necessarily appreciable in lecture. Professor Zhong appeared entirely unwilling to engage with students and frequently cut people off as they tried to ask questions. The environment created by the class did not facilitate thoughtful learning or engagement with the material in any way.
Dr. Zhong is an awful professor. Julie is amazing

The actual material was very interesting. Learning about epigenetics, sex chromosomes, and cancer was very cool. However we werent tested on this which is sad because this is what is applicable to real life. We were tested on details we covered in passing and due to the lack of a midterm we werent prepared. The class should focus on lage concepts first and then dive into the details to understand it and studies that proved this.
the course is well structured overall and the lectures are fairly well outlined, however, during lecture some questions were left unanswered.

Strengths: common themes that tie in the concepts throughout the whole course, practical uses of what we're learning. What we do in section reinforces concepts necessary to understand lecture material and is also helpful for homework. Weaknesses: readings often don't match up with the lecture material. When they do, the readings are very helpful, but when they don't, it's kind of a waste of time.

Julie Park's enrichment sessions and the textbook were my primary methods of understanding the material. Piazza was also helpful for reviewing the day before the final. I found lecture to be confusing, especially when students would ask questions and the professor would offer meandering explanations. I answered "agree" to question 5 because of how awesome enrichment was!!

I liked the way that the lectures were arranged by topic, but most of the time the format was too confusing and I didn't understand the relevance of a lot of concepts. The material on the quizzes seemed to be based on either trivial information from the lecture slides or required a lot more thought than was possible in the 15 minute time frame. Explanation of the concepts during lecture was really confusing--Professor Zhong attempted to make the concepts tie into "broader concepts" of development, but that didn't really help as the smaller details weren't really clear in the first place. Attempts to engage the class with questions were admirable but were ultimately really frustrating as the question posed was never clear, or student responses were dismissed.

The content of this course is very interesting, but. unfortunately, this module was very disorganized and hectic. The genetics concepts were taught very poorly, if at all by Zhong in lecture. The discussion sections seemed very disconnected from what we were doing in lecture, and they largely felt like a waste of time. Finally, the difficulty of the quizzes varied, but, overall, there quizzes were too hard/too demanding given the time constraints.

Strengths: the course coordinator was great, and I pretty much learned all of what I know from her. She was very well organized and explained the lectures in a way that made sense. Weaknesses: I simply could not follow lecture. There were too many complicated studies and I got lost in the jargon/methods every single time.
The material is fascinating and is very important to understand, but sometimes feels disjointed from lecture to lecture. For the most part though the class is fairly well structured and organized.

The content of this course is actually pretty interesting. It was taught terribly and actually made me hate biology and make me think of changing my major. The questions on the quizzes and the exam are worded so poorly it is more of a reading comprehension test than anything else.The class timing itself (75 minutes) is not beneficial to student learning, as the majority of people cannot pay attention for 75 minutes straight. Changing it to be a 3 day a week, 50 minute lecture, with powerpoint that make sense and quizzes that are fair, would improve the course a lot.

The professor makes the class. I thought the class was interesting, or at least had the potential to be, but Professor Zhong made it hard to really get involved in the material because everything went so fast. There wasn't a lot of valuable information on the powerpoint slides, so you couldn't rely on them a whole lot if you had questions. On the topic of questions...Don't try asking Professor Zhong questions because he will either say "Ill get to that" or he'll interrupt you in the middle of you asking to answer a question he presumes you're asking even if its not even close...And his explanations to those questions are incomprehensible because he yells into the microphone and that mumbles his words. So yeah...If you have questions just go to Julie Park (or the program director if she isn't it for you). So the strengths: cool material. The weakness: Professor Zhong. Nice guy, but not the best professor.

The course teaches the basics of development and genetics, but it goes way too fast and the concepts are extremely difficult to understand. Many students mentioned how lost they felt. Even with enrichment I struggled.
Professor Zhong often cut students off in the middle of their questions. His slides were confusing and contained way too much jargon. The class itself didn't seem organized or sequential in any way.

One strength was Professor Zhong's inclusion of writing a research proposal as our homework assignments. I really appreciated going through that process in a step-wise manner and applying what we learn in lecture to a more "real-life" project. One weakness was that there was no formal review session for basic genetic concepts. We did, however, have excellent peer tutors who offered a basic genetics review session, so if students could have the option of attending a basic genetics review session every time BIOL 103 is offered, that would be wonderful.

Some of the questions that Professor Zhong asks in class are extremely hard to understand, not because of their content but because of how they are phrased, so most of the time, the class just stares back at him blankly without knowing how to reply. That being said, the course is very strong in its contents; all of the examples provided make the concepts much easier to learn. Some of them may take a lot of time to sink in, but peer tutor hours help a LOT (cannot stress this enough). There are a lot of resources for BIOL 103 like peer tutors that help reinforce conceptsEnrichment, Piazza, discussion sections. The quizzes were also good in that they were a combination of memorization and applied knowledge. The discussion section readings also tested our knowledge of concepts very well.

The learning goals and objectives at the beginning and end of each lecture were helpful because they gave a detailed, but succinct, summary of lectures that could be intimidating due to their wide scope. This course could be improved in two main ways: 1) provide more details about experiments introduced in lecture: hypothesis, methods, conclusions. Often slides only included a picture with no accompanying text, and we would zip through this in class, making it difficult to fully understand its relationship to the themes we were covering in class, and 2) institute more "check-ins" throughout lecture, such as a simple classroom exercise or two, that allow students to make sure that they're understanding the material.

This course contained good content and on the whole seemed well-organized, but was taught in an extremely disorganized and confusing manner. Instead of teaching us the process of development first, starting with an overview of embryogenesis, and then neurogenesis, and then growth, our professor started with extremely broad themes in development, like patterning, feedback and signaling systems, and drew examples from all of the wildly varying stages of development (embryogenesis, neurogenesis, growth) at random, and out of sequential order, to illustrate these themes. This would be equivalent to teaching a history course and starting with concepts like militarism, imperialism, and balances of power, teaching each by delving into incredible detail about specific battles and events that represent the larger concept, and then, only at the end, acknowledging that they had all been relating to WWI. A normal course would FIRST go through the timeline of events of WWI, and THEN ask students to connect broader themes that explain them. It is a simple concept, but I must re-emphasize how misguided this class was in its format.

The strengths of this class were the enrichment program, the peer tutoring sessions, and the research proposal process. Without enrichment, I do not think I would have done nearly as well in this class. Professor Park re-explained everything that was so unclear in class in the best and most efficient way. The peer tutors also helped tremendously. And, the research proposal was a much-needed experience for me because I now feel very comfortable designing an experiment. The weakness in this class was lecture. Lecture always felt very rushed and questions were often left unanswered. The slides themselves were also not the most helpful in explaining topics or even complementing what Professor Zhong was saying.

I think that the lectures were weak - Professor Zhong talked too loudly frequently and too quickly. I didn't like the way they were tested as well - frequently slides that were skipped over because we ran out of time were heavily featured on the weekly quizzes.

I personally do not like the timed quizzes especially when they are Prof Zhong's quizzes because he asks questions that objectively more time than 15 minutes to fully digest and process and answer correctly. Another weakness: Prof Zhong's teaching style, he talks very quickly and interrupts students that are asking questions, which is annoying because they usually are good questions that clarify material; rushes through slides even though they might definitely be important; strengths - interesting material and didn't totally turn me off from genetics, made me realize that I actually like biology more than this class and made me able to endure it

The course itself has a lot of broad areas of information involved. I think that the quizzes are much more difficult than need be, especially considering how the information is administered by the professor. I think the the course has good information and the overall structure of the course works well, although I think most of the work we had to do did not help us learn the material.

Professor Zhong repeatedly said that we would only be tested on "general concepts," but this became a joke by the end of the class due to the trivial facts that we were supposed to pick out and remember. Don't bother trying to learn from the book either as we were told, "Only about half of the information in the book is correct."
The course could be taught in a more chronological order in terms of development. Its strengths are that it is very interesting and organized.

Course covered good amount of material, but explanations could be more clear for certain topics. I believe greater emphasis should be placed on concepts that will be tested, which I feel that this course did not do very well.

Strength is the field in general is more interesting. We finally get to see science working outside of the molecular level. We look at frogs with two heads and mice stitched together. The project/homework is also a lot more rewarding than 101 and 102's PSETS.

The course is very memorization heavy-- it relies on you picking out extremely specific information form the slides to regurgitate on quizzes and tests. The research paper that you produce over 5 weeks of homework feels very arbitrary and is much more work than the homework in 101,102 or 104. Also, the course is poorly organized. Why would genetics be in the same lecture as hormones? This feels like an afterthought.
Poorly organized, limited resources
Lectures were very confusing, and material was scattered and hard to understand.

The professor was horrible. I thought the professor for 102 was bad, but this man was worse. His accent coupled with his incredibly difficult quizzes made the class terrible. I dreaded going to the class every week. Get a new professor to teach the class.
Definitely confusing and goes into way too much detail on some topics without explaining basics

The only strength of this course is that the subject matter is interesting. Even this was tarnished by how terribly the class was taught. Lectures were too basic for the level of understanding we were expected to have on the tests. Also, there were frequent questions on examinations that no student could have reasonably answered on their own.

Weaknesses: the professor talks way to fast, speeds through the lectures and makes it very difficult to follow and learn from. The lecture slides were incomprehensible and incredibly confusing. It was extremely difficult finding a gene with putative transcription factors that also had a plethora of papers to back it up. The psets NEED to be fixed, this was very frustrating.

The material was very interesting and stimulating, and the homework provided an organized scaffold upon which students could create their hypothesis and scientific paper. A weakness of the course would be the disconnect between certain aspects of examinations and the actual lessons.

While I found that I learned and understood a lot more of the material than 102, how well I knew it was tested so poorly. It was always difficult to understand what the quizzes were asking, even if I knew the material.
The lecture did not make clear what concepts we were meant to take away and what level of detail was important

Strengths of this course are the skills that students are able to build by crafting a research proposal step-by-step with opportunities to revise it every time. That constant feedback is very helpful. The material is also very interesting and well-chosen. However, there could be a better explanation of concepts.

THIS COURSE NEEDS TO HAVE PROBLEM SETS THAT ALLOW STUDENTS TO PRACTICE AND APPLY WHAT THEY HAVE LEARNED IN CLASS!!! This course was difficult because the quizzes came out of no where, since we didnt have any practice.
Poorly organized, the Prof skips important points, and not very engaging.

I dont want to be misconstrued as being culturally insensitive, but I had an extremely difficult time understanding Professor Zhong when he spoke. He had a very thick accent and spoke too quickly. After the first couple of lectures, I gave up on attempting to follow along. I know I am not alone in feeling this way. Every other student I spoke to had a very hard time understanding him. Beyond that, I really enjoyed his enthusiasm. He is very knowledgeable.

This course is easily the worst I have taken so far at Yale. The lectures are extremely poorly organized, and it often seemed like the lecture slides were just complications of slides that were previously used by the professor for his own research. The concepts should not be presented through specific examples, but rather explained first and then substantiated through specific examples. Additionally, slides often presented data with no accompanying explanations, but we were never taught how to interpret often novel presentations of data. Finally, Professor Zhong often went through material without explaining it thoroughly, which made it difficult to follow the lectures.
It is a basic intro class. I would say the strengths are the TAs.
This course was not taught well. Even when attending the lectures every day, the important concepts we needed to learn were not articulated/ pointed out well.
Material is interesting, but it is presented in a way that makes it very difficult to understand. I think the slides and method of teaching could be improved upon.

The course does give students a solid background in genetics and development, although mostly the latter. Professor Zhong often integrates very complicated genetics/developmental concepts in his lectures, and it is often unclear what students are responsible to know. A few suggestions to improve the class: First, asking questions in lecture is difficult, given that students often don't know where to begin. It might help to start a whistling or clapping or some other way to facilitate asking questions. Additionally, Professor Zhong doesn't listen to students' nuanced questions fully, and often guesses what the question is and thus gives an answer that is not always satisfactory. Second, it might help to indicate on the slides themselves which ones students are responsible for, say, by putting a red star on slides that students do not have to know. Third, more practice with the concepts seen in class, either through problem questions during lecture to engage students or practice problems (optional) to do at home to practice for the quizzes. This was done for before the final, but more of these would certainly be helpful.

The main strength is that this course has a lot of applied learning in situational examples and case studies. If this class could be improved, it would be that certain questions on quizzes and exams are phrased very open-endedly.

The structure of the homeworks, each one being a piece of a research proposal we were writing throughout the semester, was a strength. The actual lectures themselves were a weakness, as Professor Zhong was often confusing and did not answer questions well in class. I felt like I learned much better in my discussion sections then in the actual lecture.

The course is very very detailed. It was good to learn about genetics and development in this level of great detail. Cons: very difficult to learn from lecture and because the information was so detailed, it was difficult to do outside research/ find the information in the text book.
The material itself is interesting and while the concept of writing a research proposal is really smart they gave us almost no guidance which made it more difficult and time consuming than neccesary.

Professor Zhong was not a good teacher. He did not explain the concepts well, if it hadnt been for the Professor Parks I would have failed this class. His quizzes seemed to be based on how he was feeling and arbitrary questions would appear on the quizzes consistently.

I think that the BIOL sequence does a good job teaching kids to think critically and specifically in a way that will train them to be good biologists. With that being said, I believe one of the big weaknesses of this course was that the nature of the information taught was not always tangible, which means the professor should work a little bit harder in making the information flow better so that it is easier to swallow. Additionally, I think lecture was challenging for many people because the professor did not always effectively answer questions. I happen to always ask after class, so I did not have this problem, but sometimes the professor would interrupt or misunderstand a question, which led many people astray/made them more confused. I also think the professor and the teaching scholars should be more willing to use Piazza to answer questions.

I think the quizzes every week are good because they force you to stay on top of the material. I also r ally liked the homeworks because they made you apply what you were learning in class to something you were interested in
A lot of information but this class was much better than 102 (and 202) in terms of not memorising a huge amount of specific details (gene names etc.) and instead focusing on concepts and processes.

Strengths: genetics is interesting, and there was definitely an effort to design the course for student learning. In particular the weekly quizzes forced us to stay on top of the material, and the homework assignments taught valuable research skills. Weaknesses: it's too much work between the weekly quizzes and the very significant homework assignments, especially since it's just introductory biology. Also Prof Zhong's slides were hard to follow sometimes (ie hard to understand when looking at them again to study) and often disorganized. Plus the quizzes and final exam often had ambiguous questions (with ambiguous grading) and a lot more memorization than expected.
The lectures were not very helpful in terms of comprehending material. I learned most of the information through enrichment. The lectures were also fast.
This class is not a great onein particular, the lectures are poorly organized and the quiz questions often so vague that even a strong command of the material can't ensure you a good score.
Professor Zhong cannot lecture.

The way the homeworks are structured to break up the writing of the research proposal is a huge strength. It is well-explained and I think I learned the most from those assignments. The weaknesses were that the lectures moved very quickly and were sometimes difficult to follow. When students asked questions, the most common response was "we'll get to it later," but often "it" was never explained later. I think professor Zhong had difficulty understanding students' questions.
The lectures were very difficult to understand.
There were a lot of concepts that had to be grasped in a fairly short amount of time. At times, these concepts could be presented in a more logical and gradual manner.
This course moves at a very fast pace and barely covers the material of genetics even though genetics is a main title of the course.

Professor should be more open to questions. Rewrite the lecture slides so that they are simple and relate more directly to what is being presented. Slow down when explaining concepts and simplify, many times I didn't understand a concept in class and I went home to look it up just to see that it was being explained in a way much more complicated than it needed to be.
The course is well designed, but the lectures were slightly too long.

I thought this course did a good job of providing important information that will serve me well in the future. It also challenged my thinking, and I think it made me a better student. One major weakness was the power points. While lectures were very informative and the power points were a good length, I think it would have helped to have more words on tge slides. Often, I would scramble ti write down as much as I could during lecture, but still miss explanations that would have been helpful to my understanding when reviewing my notes later!

Main weakness is that the professor does not engage well with students and begins to answer questions before listening to the full question. He is very difficult to communicate with. Strengths include a lot of interesting material.

A strength is that the course covers a large amount of material and does so pretty efficiently. I also think that a strength is that it teaches students how to write a research paper, and gives support throughout that process. I also think it is set up well to facilitate learning and the review sessions were extremely helpful for making sure the material was understood. I think that sometimes the quizzes were inconsistent and formatted questions in ways that made them hard to understand.

This course was incredibly difficult. The quizzes were not really reflective of what we learned in lecture and often required us to recall specific facts that were maybe mentioned once in class and were not in the lecture slides. No matter how hard you studied, you were never ensured a higher grade.
The lecture slides were poorly formatted and pretty bad as tools for reviewing the material. I liked the focus on experiments, but what we were expected to know was not particularly clear.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend this course if you need it as a pre-requisite for a major of if you are pre-med. However, definitely take this class on the off cycle (take it in the fall), so you have a better professor.
Yes its a prerequisite for most premeds and bio majors
You should only take this class if you have to. otherwise, you're wasting your time.
I would not recommend this course to another student.
No, bc the professor is really bad
I think genetics is a very interesting topic but this class isnt accesible to non stem students, so i would recommend it to potential biology majors.
Yes, it's a necessary part of the Biol sequence.
I don't think I would recommend this course unless you needed to take it for something or you really like genetics. The material was interesting; class was not.
Would not take this class for pleasure.

Most students will have to take it. It should be something that I recommend, but I honestly can say that it is not worth it in its current form. Placement out of 103 and taking MCDB Genetics and Developmental Biology would be much better.
Truly only if you have to. It's an intro course that desperately tries to be intellectually stimulating, but it just turns into trying to decipher slides that are unnecessarily complicated.
These are important introductory concepts to understand in order to have a basis for understanding more complex concepts in genetics and development.

No, but I know you have to take it so just do your best. Or wait for a different professor. I only took it because I knew the 104 professor was going to be good. Be prepared to hate biology at the end of it.
No. Don't recommend. Unless you're pre-med or need it as a prereq, don't put yourself through this stress and hardship...
If you take this course, it's going to be one crazy ride.

I only recommend this class if it is required for your major or if you are pre-med. So basically, if you don't have to take it, don't. It's an interesting class, but the workload is heavy and the class is really difficult.
I would only take this if I had to (as a prereq for MCDB, or as a pre-med)
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is a bit challenging, but I definitely learned a lot from it.
Unless this class is necessary or you have a genuine interest in genetics, there are other easier Sc/QR classes to take.
I think previous reviews exaggerate how bad this course is. I actually found that this course helped me learn foundational ideas and concepts about development and genetics.
I would probably not encourage a student to take this if they were not required to do so.
I would only recommend if it were required because of a major, or premed.

If you need to take it, then take it, but Prof Zhong honestly is not the best professor out there and I heard the off-cycle sequence professor is better; he's not really conducive to learning the material and talks a bit too quick and interrupts students when they're asking questions

Absolutely not. It was way too stressful for the work and how it was taught was very poor. I would not tell anyone to take it unless they absolutely needed to. Even then, the course should improve in structure since it is required for so may majors.

If it's a requirement, it's a requirement. However, if you are not in a hurry, consider taking 103/104 in the fall. Since they should have similar curves, your grade won't necessarily be better, but it will be more enjoyable.

You must take Bio103 for premed, but the question boils down to taking Bio103 in the spring or fall. I would say you can get through spring Bio103 with Zhong but understand his shortcomings as a teacher going in. Spring Bio104 is very nice so far (the teacher is a good teacher).

This is a necessary step in the biology sequence so it is mostly unavoidable. The course is very poorly organized so it will be difficult to follow. Furthermore, the development content, and to a lesser extent the genetics, will be unfamiliar to most students and the course gets very caught up in specifics without creating a helpful foundation/framework.
No.
It's not really a choice have to take it. But it was too long and confusing even though the material was interesting to really recommend
absolutley not. This course is not worth your time unless you are required to take it.
Only if you have to take it.
I would recommend this course to another student because genetics was taught in a fascinating manner and the skills developed by writing the scientific paper are valuable.
Of course not. It's not super painful if you go in knowing your grade won't reflect your learning, but it's never a pleasant experience.

I would only recommend the course if they need it for their major/premed or if they want to do research. I think it's very targeted at students who want to do biology research in grad school, not necessarily those who are just interests during in genetics or becoming a doctor
I recommend it only as a prerequisite or requisite for other courses or a major. Otherwise, I would not take this course despite the interesting material due to the way the material is taught.
Take it if you have to

I would recommend it for the reason that it is a necessary step in the bio sequence and could facilitate learning in genetics and development at a higher level where the purpose of lectures was more to-the-point and where key concepts could be drilled in. Lecture outlines often made it hard to follow what Professor Zhong was talking about, instead of easier, and I thought there was an expectation of background knowledge in genetics that not many students had. Many lectures included anecdotes about research with unclear connections to the actual material that we were expected to know.
No. Take this class only if you need to, and if you can, take it off sequence.
don't take it w weimin zhong
It is required for some majors. I don't think I would recommend it if you don't need to take it.
Only to those who need it as a requirement.
Not particularly. I mean, it's an intro course, so anyone in the sciences has to take it, but the intro course level also means it has to be broadened to the point of boredom.

Most students taking this class do it to fulfill their pre-requirements for a life sciences related major. I would not recommend this class to students wanting to fulfill a science credit or for pleasure.
Yes, this is an important part of the biology sequence and provided me research skills I will use beyond the class if I am to do my own work in a lab or in the field.

It is often a necessary course so if you have to take it, take it off-sequence (take 103/4 in the fall instead of spring).Those semesters have a much less difficult time understanding the professor. So no, I would not recommend taking 103 in the spring.
Its actually very interesting if youre interested in genetics although there are likely better bio courses.
No, unless they have to take it. It just causes a lot of stress because you can study hours for the exam and it seems like you never saw the material before when you take it.

I would recommend really only if the sequence is required. I don't think that any of the courses in the BIOL sequence are ones you should take out of interest (because they have developed to cultivate very particular skills and are not exactly for recreation, even though I enjoyed them). With that being said, many of the worries I had about the sequence were not as bad as I had hoped. For instance, there is this general understanding amongst pre-meds on campus that Zhong is a bad teacher and if you can help it, you should take the BIOL sequence in the fall with the other professor, and I don't agree with that. I was very tempted to bail but I am glad I didn't because, although Zhong wasn't always the most amazing teacher, he was clear if you paid attention in class and took active notes, and he answers questions incredibly well if you approach him one on one (which isn't something I think most students consider). BIOL 103 with Zhong gets a worse rep than I think it deserves, and I'd encourage whoever is considering taking the sequence in the fall to consider this comment. I will say, though, that my favorite sequence was 102 with Mooseker (because I liked him a lot, was able to work hard, learn a lot, and get very tangible skills), so maybe that will give you some insight on how I feel about the sequence in general. Still, consider just putting your nose down and working hard through 103 instead of postponing! You'll be surprised how much you learn and stuff.
This module is better than 102 for sure
As with all of the intro bio sequence, it is useful as a prereq but if not for that or pure interest there are better, more interesting and engaging Sc classes out there.

Unpopular opinion: 103 with Prof Zhong was better than 102 with Prof Mooseker. There were still many issues, but I felt like there was more of an effort to present the material in a way that would facilitate student learning. I do think genetics is always interesting, so I might be a little biased. One thing to be aware of is that the workload is higher than any of the other modules, because there are weekly quizzes (with too much memorization/specific examples) AND very extensive weekly homework assignments.
Only if needed for a major.
Everyone taking this course has to take this course, and if it wasn't a prerequisite for almost every STEM major, the course would be empty.
Only if it is required.

Most people taking this course probably have to take it for a major or pre-med requirement. If it is not required, I would not recommend it as it is one of the harder courses in the bio series. With that said, if you are required to take some bio, I wouldn't stop at 101 and 102 because 103, despite the challenge, is very interesting.
I would not recommend this course to anyone.

This is a good survey, especially of of the various fields in developmental biology. However, if one was looking for introduction to biology (not as a major requirement) BIOL 101/102 would be more than sufficient.
If you can avoid it, do not take this course. It is a terrible course that constantly contradicts itself and will make you wish you had never signed up.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. For some, this is not an option, as it a required course for several majors. But if you are looking for a fundamental and challenging course in genetics and development, I'd recommend. The homework assignments require a great deal of time and effort, but they are the most rewarding in the Bio sequence.
You're going to take this class cause you have to. Grind your teeth and get through it champ.
Only if it is required by your major.
I would recommend this course to anothet student as long as they understood that it would be challenging and require a lot of work.
Yes, but only because it is a prerequisite for so many other classes.
Yes, it is a good intro course for these subjects and you cover a lot of material.
This course was hell. Take biology off-sequence if you love yourself.
Cool information, pretty lame course. All of the other bio courses are better.
